page.title: 14Local History.
page.content: Milborne St. Andrew is a very old settlement. Recorded history starts with a Charter from King Athelstan who gave the land at Meleburn to endow his new Abbey at Milton in A.D. 843 (when checked from 925 - 940.) Milborne is not mentioned again until the mid 15th century, where it is termed Milborne Abbotson, Andrueston, Churcheston, Deverel, Mamford, Michaelston and Symondeston. Milborne Slileham was merged with Milborne St. Andrew in 1933. The Church was built in 1067 and has two fine Norman arches, restorations were carried out in 1878. The village has close conections with John Morton, born 1410 who became Lord Chancellor, Archibishop of Canterbury and eventually Cardinal in the reign of Henry VII. The Manor house where he lived still stands.
